descript.abstract: This dataset is a compilation of boundary location polygons for 167 hydraulic mine pits located in northern California. This dataset was compiled from three sources, Topographically Occurring Mine Symbols (TOMS) database produced by the California Department of Conservation (2001), Yeend W.E., 1974, and on-screen digitizing, using current (2015) satellite imagery, of additional hydraulic mine pits not contained in either of these sources.
descript.purpose: This dataset of hydraulic mine pits was compiled as part of a regional research study attempting to model fish tissue mercury concentrations for streams in the northern Sierra Nevada mountains of California, by using multiple landscape characteristics as model input.
descript.supplinf: References Cited: California Department of Conservation, 2001, Topographic Occurring Mine Symbols: Office of Mine Reclamation, Abandoned Mined Lands Unit, accessed 02/2010 at http://www.conservation.ca.gov/omr/abandoned_mine_lands/toms/ Yeend Warren.E., 1974, Gold-bearing gravel of the ancestral Yuba River, Sierra Nevada, California: U.S. Geological Survey Professional Paper 772, 44 p.

srcinfo.srccontr: Polygon shapefile defining areas of hydraulic mine pits.
The imagery was used to delineate the hydraulic mines that were not mapped in Yeend’s report nor found in the Topographic Occurring Mines Symbol database.
Used to determine appropriate names for some hydraulic mine pits.

procstep.procdesc: An original paper map of hydraulic mined areas from the Yeend publication was digitized rectified, attributed, and output as a geospatial dataset, in the format of Esri’s ArcInfo polygon “coverage”.
The Yeend based coverage was converted to a shapefile and projected to the Albers Equal Area projection of the final shapefile.
TheTopographically Occurring Mine Symbols (TOMS) shapefile was queried for "Type" = "Diggings" and these selected polygons were merged with the Yeend shapefile.

Additional hydraulic pit polygons not contained in either the Yeend or TOMS sources were digitizied on screen in ArcGIS using current (2015) satellite imagery in the background at 1:10,000 screen resolution.

Hydraulic mine pit polygons from the TOMS datasource were compared to with current (2015) satellite imagery. Polygon boundaries were adjusted to better match hydraulic mine pit outlines observable in satellite imagery where necessary.
The area of each hydraulic pit polygon was calculated using the "Calculate Geometry" tool in the XTools toolset (Data East, 2015).

attrdomv.udom: Hydraulic pit name derived from current topographic maps. In some instances when a pit feature was not specifically named, a name was assigned based on a nearby named feature (mine, town, etc.). In cases when no prominent named features were present on the topographic map, a value of "unknown" was assigned. Names are not unique.
